description.narrative:
This project is based on the theory of change that if women and youth are empowered, offered opportunities in economic development,and operate in a more gender-sensitive environment, then this will allow them to play a greater role in promoting household live hoods
The project will use a rights based and gender-responsive approach; which aims to empower beneficiaries to make positive contribution to sustainable development in their communities. Skills trainings will be learner-centered and orientatedtowards developing new competences and credentials, including business and entrepreneurial skills that empower them to develop their own innovative ideas. The overall goal of the project is to empower youth and women to secure meaningful employment and self-employment.
The project targets at least 50 women and youth for TVET and other skills training
In Somaliland, employment rates are low where only 26% of working age adults are employed in urban areas and 32.7% are employed in rural areas . A labor force survey conducted in Borama, Hargeisa <(>&<)> Burao revealed that total employment to population ratios for those aged 15 – 64 years were 28.5% and 16.7% for males andfemales respectively. Levels of employment to population ratio for males are generally higher than those of females . Entrepreneurship rates among young people are still very low, particularly for women, sometimes due to stereotyping associated with what jobs women should or can do. The demand for skilled labor force in Somaliland is growing in sectors such as hospitality and construction among others. However, the current labor force lacks the required skills, competencies and attitude to take advantage of the job opportunities. In Somaliland, women have less than half the opportunities afforded to men with Overall Gender Gap of 0.45 . Despite the government’s commitments on gender equality, representations and participation of women in governance and decision-making is still very low. This is attributed to policy barriers, limited access to information, unfavorable cultural biases. This left women with limited opportunities to acquire political experience to run for national and local offices. This was manifested in the recently concluded elections where majority of women candidates lost the election. The above is reflective of the project site. Therefore, the project will help youth and women to acquire the necessary skills to get or create jobs. Also, investing in girls and women will create a ripple effect that benefits individualwomen, families and communities; thus promoting economic.

participating-org.narrative: Candle Light for Health and Education (CLHE) works in the Toghdeer region of Somalia and was founded in 1995. Its mandate is to contribute to setting up sustainable structures in education and healthcare. Its most important target group consists of women and other marginalised groups, such as returning refugees. CHLE is also working with former militia members and tries to integrate them in society. CLHE works closely with the local authorities, leaders and others. Its work includes formal and informaleducation, training,preventive healthcare, rehabilitating small school buildings, and small-scale income generating activities. CLHE also works on the environment. It is of the opinion that deforestation has a negative impact on cattle, which has negative consequences for people's health and nutrition. Not enough good grazing land and a lack of water increase people's mobility, disrupting education programs. Therelationship between Oxfam Novib and CLHE began in 1996. CLHE's organisation capacities havesince improved.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
